title: Cressida Dick profile: High-flier thrust into national spotlight
text:
Arsenal scouts turned away from Lincoln match as ground was full 
New Metropolitan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick has been described as the most talented woman officer of her generation. 
The daughter of two Oxford dons, she was educated at the private Oxford High School for Girls before studying agriculture and forest sciences at the university’s Balliol College where she was women’s rowing captain and wicket-keeper for the women’s cricket team. 
After graduating, Ms Dick worked briefly for an accountancy firm before joining the Met in 1983. 
Tipped as a high flyer from the beginning, she joined as a beat constable in the West End in 1983 and quickly rose through the ranks. 
Following several promotions she left to join Thames Valley and returned to Oxford for three years as an area commander before returning to London in 2001. 
Her career continued to flourish with stints as head of the Met’s diversity unit and the Operation Trident squad tackling an explosion in so-called Jamaican Yardie gang violence in London. 
She had responsibility for some of the most sensitive inquiries including phone hacking and the reinvestigation of the Lawrence murder that ended in the conviction of two of the teenager’s killers, nearly 20 years after the first botched inquiry. 
She was also in charge of all the UK police operations following the tsunami that devastated south east Asia on Boxing Day 2004. 
However, the talented officer was thrust into the national spotlight in 2005 when innocent Brazilian electrician Jean Charles de Menezes was shot dead by police in a counter terrorism operation she commanded in south London. Cressida Dick commanded the operation in which innocent Jean Charles de Menezes was shot dead by police 
The Brazilian electrician was killed by firearms officers in a Tube carriage at Stockwell station after being mistaken for a terrorist who they believed was about to detonate a suicide bomb. 
When the force was later prosecuted for breaching health and safety laws she told the Old Bailey that she used the word “stop” and expected a “conventional armed challenge” from firearms officers. After convicting the Met, the jury cleared Ms Dick of any blame. 
In later interviews she described his death as a “terrible tragedy” saying she believed he was the victim of “the most extraordinary and terrible circumstances.” 
She added: “It was my job and my duty to get on with it. I had to explain what happened, tell the truth and stand up and be counted.” 
Known for her cool and calm head in running complex inquiries, she gained admiration for her resilience and was promoted up the ranks despite coming under scrutiny over the shooting. 
Ms Dick left the Met in 2014 soon after she was moved from her role as head of counter terror policing, a position she held since 2011. She took up a secretive director-general post at the Foreign Office. More about:
